did.abstract: The records consist of financial information concerning the Norwich Typographical Union. Formed to protect workers in the various printing occupations, the Norwich Typographical Union was a local branch of the International Typographical Union and was active from the 1860s to the 1980s.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Norwich Typographical Union was formed in the 1860s as a way for the city's printers, and those employed in various aspects of printing, to maintain printing and labor standards. The Norwich Typographical Union was organized first as a part of the National Typographical Union, and then in 1869 under the International Typographical Union. Under the International Typographical Union the Norwich Typographical Union was number 100 of the various local branches of the union, and was identified as Norwhich Typographical Union No. 100. The union was comprised of workers from several of the the local newspapers, including the Norwich Evening Record, The Norwich Bulletin, the New London Telegraph, and New London's The Day. The Norwich Typographical Union continued to operate under the International Typographical Union until 1986 when the latter disbanded.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The records consist of two ledgers. The primary ledger contains the financial records for the union for the years 1895 to 1899. The information consists of the names of the members of the union, their dues to the union, and their weekly wages. There is also information concerning the union's treasury. The second ledger contains blank membership cards to the International Typographical Union. There are currently only three cards remaining, all the others having been torn out.
